title: Booker Prize winners: Who won after judging panel awards two writers?
text:
Two women share the Booker Prize this year (Picture: Jeff Spicer/Getty Images)

Two writers have made history by both winning the 2019 Booker Prize, despite the rules forbidding it.

Even though the judges were repeatedly told they were not permitted to split the prize two ways, according to organisers, they unanimously ‘staged a sit-in’ until their choices were accepted.

Chairman of the jury and Hay Festival founder Peter Florence said: ‘The more we talked about them, the more we treasured them and wanted them both as winners.

‘Laws are invaluable. Rules are adapted to the circumstance. The only result that we were happy with was to award the prize this year to both.

‘There are things they shared. They are both fully engaged novels. They address the world today.’

Who won the 2019 Booker Prize?

Canadian author and poet Margaret Atwood and British writer Bernadine Evaristo were the joint winners of the Booker Prize this year.

Atwood won for her The Handmaid’s Tale sequel The Testaments, and Evaristo won for the polyvocal Girl, Woman, Other, which explores modern black British womanhood.

The writers will split the £50,000 prize money.

With this win, Atwood has become the fourth person and the second woman ever to win the Booker prize twice, joining JM Coetzee, Peter Cary and Hilary Mantel. At 79, she is also the oldest person to have won the prize.

She previously won the Booker Prize for her 2000 novel, The Blind Assassin.

On the subject of Atwood’s The Testaments, Florence said: ‘Now it looks more politically urgent than ever. There is a need now to look at what complicity and what resilience and what resistance might look like.’

Margaret Atwood poses with her book ‘The Testaments’ (Picture: TOLGA AKMEN/AFP via Getty Images)

Both authors expressed their happiness at sharing the prize, with Atwood saying: ‘It would have been quite embarrassing for a person of my age and stage to have won the whole thing and thereby have kept a younger one, at a different stage of their career, from going through that door’

With this win, Evaristo, 60, has become the first black woman to take home the Booker Prize, an honour which she said she hopes ‘doesn’t last too long.’

Bernardine Evaristo poses with her book ‘Girl, Woman, Other’ (Picture TOLGA AKMEN/AFP via Getty Images)

Florence said Evaristo’s work gave readers a ‘wonderful spectrum of black British women today. This book is groundbreaking’.

On the subject of her win, Evaristo said she was ‘absolutely delighted to share it with the legend that is Margaret Atwood.’

Booker Prize shortlist for 2019 Margaret Atwood (joint winner) – The Testaments Bernardine Evaristo (joint winner) – Girl, Woman, Other Lucy Ellmann – Ducks, Newburyport Chigozie Obioma – An Orchestra of Minorities Salman Rushdie – Quichotte Elif Shafak – 10 Minutes 38 Seconds in This Strange World

Booker literary director Gaby Wood said she respected the jury’s choice to rebel, despite an order from foundation chairwoman Helena Kennedy that the rules must be abided by.

Wood said: ‘It is always the jury’s decision. I support the means by which the judges arrived at their decision.

‘It wasn’t a fighting gesture. It was a generous one.

‘If someone makes a revolutionary gesture, you have to accept it. You don’t have to say, ‘I agree with it’.’

The Booker Prize has previously been split twice – first between Nadine Gordimer and Stanley Middleton in 1974, and again between Michael Ondaatje and Barry Unsworth in 1992.

Rules were since brought in to prevent any further divisions of the prize.
